newsitem.title: USA: New U.S. $50 bill aimed at reducing counterfeiting.
newsitem.headline: New U.S. $50 bill aimed at reducing counterfeiting.

text.p: U.S. officials unveiled a redesigned $50 note on Thursday, saying several new security features would significantly reduce counterfeiting.
The new note, which follows a redesigned $100 note, will be issued in the fall, ultimately replacing all $46.5 billion in $50 notes currently in circulation.

"Since its introduction, the new $100 bill has been extremely effective against counterfeiting and has been well received by the American people," said Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin at the unveiling.

In the first year of its issuance, the new $100 note reduced counterfeiting to 1/18th of its previous volume, according to the U.S. Secret Service. The new note represents over one third of all $100 bills in circulation.
The new $50 note includes security features, including watermarks, microprinting and color-shifting ink that should greatly hamper counterfeiting efforts, the officials said.

"Our currency is trusted and accepted by people throughout the world. Because of this special status, the protection of our currency from counterfeiting has long been a priority," said Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan.
